dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Overseas spectators are now required to attend the Tokyo Olympics, according to the organizing committee.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Overseas spectators are now required to attend the Tokyo Olympics, according to the organizing committee.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Overseas spectators will be prohibited from attending the Summer Olympics in Tokyo, the games' organizing committee announced Saturday, a move they hope will mitigate the concerns of Japanese citizens over the risk that the games will seed Covid-19 outbreaks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, required? That's the opposite of what I expected—isn't that just inviting more risk?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, required? That's the opposite of what I expected-isn't that just inviting more risk?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they made this call completely on their own, ignoring even the International Olympic Committee.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they made this call completely on their own, ignoring even the International Olympic Committee.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Tokyo Organizing Committee made the decision jointly with national and local governments in Japan and the International Olympic and Paralympic Committees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's wild. And they claim zero tickets were sold overseas, but AP says it's actually around 10 million?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild. And they claim zero tickets were sold overseas, but A P says it's actually around ten million?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the organizers, approximately 600,000 tickets were sold overseas, although the Associated Press reported that number is closer to 1 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And no refunds either—Toshiro Muto says the government will cover cancellation fees for flights and hotels.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And no refunds either-Toshiro Muto says the government will cover cancellation fees for flights and hotels.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Tokyo Organizing Committee asserted that refunds for tickets would be issued, but Tokyo 2020 Chief Executive Officer Toshiro Muto said cancellation fees related to airline travel and accommodations previously booked would not be covered.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So they're basically forcing international fans to either show up or lose their money? That feels… aggressive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So they're basically forcing international fans to either show up or lose their money? That feels... aggressive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It does. And get this—they won't even decide on domestic crowd limits until late next month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does. And get this-they won't even decide on domestic crowd limits until late next month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Muto said a determination on capacity limits at venues for domestic spectators would be made before the end of next month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Japan's had over 4.6 million COVID cases and 90,000 deaths… but 80% of people still want the Games to go ahead?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, Japan's had over four point six million COVID cases and ninety thousand deaths... but eighty percent of people still want the Games to go ahead?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although Japan has managed the pandemic better than most countries, with fewer than 460,000 confirmed cases and 9,000 deaths nationwide, Japanese are not in favor of proceeding with hosting the Olympics. About 80% of Japanese believe the games, which are scheduled to begin in July, should be postponed again or canceled altogether, according to a survey by national broadcaster NHK.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, according to NHK. But 154,000 athletes have already declined to participate, along with coaches and media threatening to boycott.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, according to N H K. But one hundred fifty four thousand athletes have already declined to participate, along with coaches and media threatening to boycott.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some 15,400 athletes will enter Japan to compete, in addition to coaches, officials, sponsors and members of the media.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It sounds like a total mess. And the organizing committee straight up said their goal is to "cause confusion" to discourage travel plan changes?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It sounds like a total mess. And the organizing committee straight up said their goal is to cause confusion to discourage travel plan changes?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In order to give clarity to ticket holders living overseas and to enable them to adjust their travel plans at this stage, the parties on the Japanese side have come to the conclusion that they will not be able to enter into Japan at the time of the Olympic and Paralympic Games, the Tokyo organizing committee said in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That's the quote. They want to make it too late for people to back out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the quote. They want to make it too late for people to back out.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, the torch relay starts Monday in Hiroshima with just 10 runners?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, the torch relay starts Monday in Hiroshima with just ten runners?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The torch relay for the games will begin Thursday in Fukushima Prefecture and will last four months, with roughly 10,000 runners traversing the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it ends at a shopping mall in Tokyo. Not exactly the usual grand finish.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it ends at a shopping mall in Tokyo. Not exactly the usual grand finish.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It will conclude at National Stadium in Tokyo during the opening ceremony, scheduled to take place on July 23.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, Suga government isn't lifting the state of emergency—hospital beds are even more overwhelmed now than in January.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, Suga government isn't lifting the state of emergency-hospital beds are even more overwhelmed now than in January.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Earlier this week, Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga announced the government planned to lift the state of emergency in Tokyo on Sunday. The utilization rate of hospital beds has improved to the point that the state of emergency can be lifted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it feels like they're just plowing ahead no matter what.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it feels like they're just plowing ahead no matter what.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: At what cost, though? This could backfire so badly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: At what cost, though? This could backfire so badly.

artist_script:
HostA: Overseas spectators are now required to attend the Tokyo Olympics, according to the organizing committee.
HostB: Wait, required? That’s the opposite of what I expected—isn’t that just inviting more risk?
HostA: Yeah, and they made this call completely on their own, ignoring even the International Olympic Committee.
HostB: That’s wild. And they claim zero tickets were sold overseas, but AP says it’s actually around 10 million?
HostA: Exactly. And no refunds either—Toshiro Muto says the government will cover cancellation fees for flights and hotels.
HostB: So they’re basically forcing international fans to either show up or lose their money? That feels… aggressive.
HostA: It does. And get this—they won’t even decide on domestic crowd limits until late next month.
HostB: Meanwhile, Japan’s had over 4.6 million COVID cases and 90,000 deaths… but 80% of people still want the Games to go ahead?
HostA: Yeah, according to NHK. But 154,000 athletes have already declined to participate, along with coaches and media threatening to boycott.
HostB: It sounds like a total mess. And the organizing committee straight up said their goal is to “cause confusion” to discourage travel plan changes?
HostA: That’s the quote. They want to make it too late for people to back out.
HostB: Meanwhile, the torch relay starts Monday in Hiroshima with just 10 runners? That’s… minimalist.
HostA: And it ends at a shopping mall in Tokyo. Not exactly the usual grand finish.
HostB: Plus, Suga government isn’t lifting the state of emergency—hospital beds are even more overwhelmed now than in January.
HostA: Honestly, it feels like they’re just plowing ahead no matter what.
HostB: At what cost, though? This could backfire so badly.
